entities: United Nations Mission in Ethiopia and Eritrea
summary:
The Security Council adopted Resolution 1312 (2000) on 31 July 2000, recalling previous resolutions on the Ethiopia-Eritrea conflict. The Council established the United Nations Mission in Ethiopia and Eritrea (UNMEE) with up to 100 military observers and civilian support staff until 31 January 2001. The mission's mandate includes: 

* Establishing and maintaining liaison with the parties
* Visiting military headquarters and units
* Verifying the cessation of hostilities
* Preparing for a Military Coordination Commission
* Assisting in planning for a future peacekeeping operation

The Council welcomed discussions between the UN and OAU on cooperation in implementing the Cessation of Hostilities Agreement. It called on the parties to provide access, assistance, and protection to the Mission and facilitate the deployment of mine action experts. 

The Council also decided that measures imposed by resolution 1298 (2000) shall not apply to equipment and technical assistance for the UN Mine Action Service. It stressed the importance of border delimitation and demarcation and requested the Secretary-General to plan for a peacekeeping operation and provide periodic reports on the Mission. The Council decided to remain seized of the matter.
